Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Peri-operative Lidocaine for Radical Retropubic Prostatectomy

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either lidocaine 2% or saline 0.9%

Participants.evidence: recruiting 76 men scheduled for open retropubic radical prostatectomy

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either lidocaine 2% or saline 0.9%

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate whether intra-operative intravenous lidocaine combined with a postoperative 24-hour subcutaneous lidocaine infusion reduces pain and hospital stay after radical retropubic prostatectomy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative hospital stay.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sequentially numbered opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included participants, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: recruiting 76 men scheduled for open retropubic radical prostatectomy

Number_Analysed.evidence: 75 participants were analysed (37 lidocaine, 38 saline) using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Lidocaine reduced the postoperative hospital stay by a mean (95% CI) of 1.3 (0.3–2.4) days, p = 0.017.

Harms.evidence: No significant differences in adverse events were reported between groups.
